results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Echuca’, captures a visit to the township of Echuca on the Murray River in Victoria as well as travels along the river itself. Wallace focuses on travelling the river and also on the historic buildings in Echuca itself.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Ehuca’
00:00:20:00 paddle steamer travelling on the Murray River.
00:01:26:00 to 00:02:50:00 historic public buildings and houses around Echuca township
00:01:53:00 historic ‘Log Buggy’ in Echuca which holds a felled log from the nearby Moira Forest
00:03:04:00 steam rollers in Echuca
00:04:22:00 Echuca-Moama Bridge over the Murray River
00:05:02:00 motor traffic and streets in Echuca
00:05:04:00 St Mary’s Catholic Church in Echuca
00:05:39:00 Paddle Steamer Adelaide, berthed as an exhibit in the Hopwood Gardens in Echuca, in the 1960s
00:07:58:00 passengers on a paddle steamer on the river
00:08:55:00 water skiing on the river
00:09:03:00 ‘Weir & Lock No 26’ at Torrumbarry
00:10:07:00 logging and sawmill on the riverbank
00:12:35:00 open fire barbeque and picnic on the riverbank
00:13:59:00 examples of fungi along the river
00:14:50:00 group gathering with guitarist at dusk

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows scenes from around the Northern Territory as Wallace and companions travel by car, with what appears to be camping gear packed on the roof, to Kulera, Finke River and Tempe Downs. As always, Wallace films the various landscapes as he travels.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Kulgera 168’ followed by views of the long dusty red road ahead from the moving car and a handmade sign for ‘Goody Lookout’
00:00:30:00 sign ‘Finke River’, the river and a low bridge which the travellers’ car crosses
00:01:05:00 metalwork sign for ‘NTRB Henbury Meteorites Reserve’ followed by driving scenes through dusty scrub
00:03:14:00 a hopping kangaroo and a Northern Territory magpie goose walks through long grasses
00:03:35:00 old cattleyards
00:03:45:00 Kings Canyon and many views of surrounding countryside
00:09:46:00 a golden full moon at night

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part one of two and is titled ‘Festival City’. Wallace and companions travel by car to Adelaide in South Australia, filming the trip as they go.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Festival City’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:02:18:00 ‘Waterfalls Gully’ enroute to Adelaide
00:03:15:00 women posing with their cameras for the filmmaker’s camera.
00:03:39:00 women standing in front of a rock walk before climbing.
00:04:49:00 Adelaide Arts Centre.
00:05:16:00 paddle boats and fountain on the Torrens River in Adelaide.
00:06:31:00 churches in Adelaide.
00:07:09:00 camping alongside a pop-up van.
00:08:06:00 looking at an outdoor art exhibition.
00:09:42:00 sheep in a paddock.
00:10:03:00 historic ‘Peerless Roller Mills’ building in ‘Birdwood’, South Australia.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film shows a trip to Wilson’s Promontory, Victoria including the beach at Tidal River and a group of people hiking around the prom.

Originally made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:38:00 a banksia tree
00:01:02:00 group of people walking onto a beach with large boulders
00:01:37:00 taking photos on the shoreline
00:02:35:00 woman sketching
00:05:49:00 a little lizard
00:06:27:00 group of people hiking
00:07:43:00 man sitting on a rock looking over a view
00:08:05:00 group of people watching the view
00:09:56:00 the river going into the sea
00:12:23:00 the footbridge at Tidal River
00:14:12:00 a rosella on a branch and feeding from someone’s hand

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Rhodesia (Zimbabwe) and South Africa.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 several large passenger and cargo ships at alongside a dock, with mountains in the background.
00:01:20:00 a large ship wrecked and sitting on a reef or rocks off the shore.
00:02:30:00 scenes of mountains.
00:03:00:00 views of city gardens.

group.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, filmmaker Billy travels by ship to Fiji, then Honolulu, Hawaii and on to Canada. The film gives an indication of what it was like to travel by ship around the Pacific in the 1960s. Featured in the film is the passenger ship ‘Arcadia’ which was built in Scotland for P&O Cruises (original name, ‘The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company’) in 1953, for trips between Britain and Australia. Throughout the 1960s and early 1970s ‘Arcadia’ became a cruise liner on the trans-Pacific routes including the West Coast of America. Near the end of the film Billy shows a few scenes from ‘Stanley Park’ in Vancouver, Canada which included the ‘Zoo and children’s farmyard’ at the time, which has since been closed.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 a large passenger ship the ‘Arcadia’ sails through a bay
00:01:40:00 formal public gardens
00:02:02:00 looking across a bay toward mountains in the background
00:02:31:00 ‘P&O-Orient Line’ boarding ramp
00:02:49:00 military band uniforms indicate Fiji
00:02:50:00 an elaborate colonial style building
00:02:55:00 busy town streets with vintage model cars and police conducting traffic in traditional uniform
00:03:45:00 boys having a pillow fight on poles that are placed across a pool
00:04:10:00 scenes from ‘Arcadia’ at sea
00:04:50:00 night time scenes around a bay
00:05:25:00 a grand public building named ‘Aloma’ (probably in Hawaii)
00:05:55:00 scenes around a busy town
00:06:05:00 women performing traditional dances in Hawaii
00:07:50:00 tourists on a beach between mountains and buildings
00:08:20:00 traditional long boat surfing with paddles
00:08:50:00 board surfing
00:09:40:00 town scenes in Hawaii including an American sailor and US mailbox
00:10:10:00 great vintage cars, circa 1960s and earlier
00:10:45:00 1960s style motels
00:11:30:00 sunbathers on a beach
00:13:20:00 passenger ship steaming through a bay
00:15:17:00 lovely older couple smiling at the camera with a vintage bus in the background
00:15:24:00 ‘Canadian Pacific’ containers on a dock
00:16:03:00 ‘Stanley Park’ gardens in autumn
00:16:15:00 penguins and bears in enclosures in the zoo which was part of ‘Stanley Park’

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the Russian cities of Leningrad and Moscow.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 some quick views the ‘Latvia’ passenger ship in sail
00:00:20:00 scenes in a European city including some construction sites
00:00:52:00 the domes of the St Petersburg Cathedral (also called Church of the resurrection of Christ or Church of the Saviour on Spilled Blood) in St Petersburg, Russia
00:02:21:00 looking at the St Petersburg Cathedral framed in the distance through snowy tree branches
00:02:40:00 Red Square in Moscow, Russia
00:03:39:00 St Basil’s Cathedral in Moscow, Russia
00:04:27:00 snow on people and traffic in Moscow
00:05:17:00 pedestrians and cars on the streets of Moscow
00:06:50:00 cars driving alongside a river in Moscow
00:07:05:00 a crowd watches a military parade of personal and armoured vehicles
00:09:03:00 snowy streets
00:09:49:00 airplane exhibition
00:10:27:00 people tobogganing in the snow amongst some trees
00:11:00:00 people take to their skis in a snowy forest

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Japan, Tahiti, New York and Funchal in Portugal. A feature of the film is a glimpse of what appears to be the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York when under construction.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a busy scene of junks sailing around a harbour, likely to be in Japan
00:00:30:00 for a large passenger ship being welcomed to port by a military band and Japanese geishas in costume
00:00:53:00 street scenes of a Japanese town, pagodas and historic buildings
00:01:43:00 a statue of an imposing looking man atop a rock formation
00:02:00:00 views of temples, traditional buildings and gardens
00:03:20:00 views of waterways, boats, ships, hills, some snow, and pagodas
00:06:20:00 view across the sea to some picturesque mountains in the background
00:07:37:00 some townhouses along the shoreline
00:08:01:00 a large passenger ship at a dock
00:08:38:00 the Stature of Liberty appears followed by the New York skyline
00:09:39:00 views of New York buildings including a glimpse of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during construction
00:09:55:00 a harbour view with ferries and piers and the Empire State Building in the background
00:11:20:00 a large tugboat chugs across the water
00:11:38:00 passengers on board a ship deck
00:13:28:00 Billy’s friends or relatives smile at the camera in a garden
00:14:29:00 a ship in port with some great cars of the era in the foreground
00:15:11:00 a public square and fountain, possibly in Portugal
00:16:26:00 decorative fishing boats being loaded in a port
results.description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Japan, Tahiti, New York and Funchal in Portugal. A feature of the film is a glimpse of what appears to be the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York when under construction.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a busy scene of junks sailing around a harbour, likely to be in Japan
00:00:30:00 for a large passenger ship being welcomed to port by a military band and Japanese geishas in costume
00:00:53:00 street scenes of a Japanese town, pagodas and historic buildings
00:01:43:00 a statue of an imposing looking man atop a rock formation
00:02:00:00 views of temples, traditional buildings and gardens
00:03:20:00 views of waterways, boats, ships, hills, some snow, and pagodas
00:06:20:00 view across the sea to some picturesque mountains in the background
00:07:37:00 some townhouses along the shoreline
00:08:01:00 a large passenger ship at a dock
00:08:38:00 the Stature of Liberty appears followed by the New York skyline
00:09:39:00 views of New York buildings including a glimpse of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during construction
00:09:55:00 a harbour view with ferries and piers and the Empire State Building in the background
00:11:20:00 a large tugboat chugs across the water
00:11:38:00 passengers on board a ship deck
00:13:28:00 Billy’s friends or relatives smile at the camera in a garden
00:14:29:00 a ship in port with some great cars of the era in the foreground
00:15:11:00 a public square and fountain, possibly in Portugal
00:16:26:00 decorative fishing boats being loaded in a port
description_for_label:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Japan, Tahiti, New York and Funchal in Portugal. A feature of the film is a glimpse of what appears to be the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York when under construction.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a busy scene of junks sailing around a harbour, likely to be in Japan
00:00:30:00 for a large passenger ship being welcomed to port by a military band and Japanese geishas in costume
00:00:53:00 street scenes of a Japanese town, pagodas and historic buildings
00:01:43:00 a statue of an imposing looking man atop a rock formation
00:02:00:00 views of temples, traditional buildings and gardens
00:03:20:00 views of waterways, boats, ships, hills, some snow, and pagodas
00:06:20:00 view across the sea to some picturesque mountains in the background
00:07:37:00 some townhouses along the shoreline
00:08:01:00 a large passenger ship at a dock
00:08:38:00 the Stature of Liberty appears followed by the New York skyline
00:09:39:00 views of New York buildings including a glimpse of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during construction
00:09:55:00 a harbour view with ferries and piers and the Empire State Building in the background
00:11:20:00 a large tugboat chugs across the water
00:11:38:00 passengers on board a ship deck
00:13:28:00 Billy’s friends or relatives smile at the camera in a garden
00:14:29:00 a ship in port with some great cars of the era in the foreground
00:15:11:00 a public square and fountain, possibly in Portugal
00:16:26:00 decorative fishing boats being loaded in a port

group.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).
